How are hard determinism, chaos theory and quantum randomness related in the philosophy of free will? Hard determinism belongs to classical/mechanistic physics. Chaos theory belongs to non-linear complexity physics. Quantum indeterminacy (not randomness)arises from wave-particle duality whose observable significance is related to the smallness of Planck’s constant, and therefore becomes crucial only in microcosmic physics. Freewill is related to the hypercomplex domain human psychology, and has not yet been reduced to any physical laws. [And may nver be, but one cannot predict the future.] 20 Aug 17

1It would based upon the current model. If these classes of particles are really probabilities, and points, and not particles.I acknowledge that it works for lots of observations. Yet, the use of point-forces and quantum probabilities have critical weaknesses:a. Proton wrong 'spin'b. No viable solutions beyond Hydrogen (or inner electrons like (1,0,0) even in Hydrogen) - yet it works very well for outer electrons of most atoms.c. DFT and TDDFT discontinuities and required refinements (Hartree > Kolm-Sham, Perdew-Burke, GGA, and so on) because as much as it works well sometimes, sometimes it is infinitely wrong.d. and many others2However, if there is other models that achieve the results of the current model, the we are back to pure determinism.I remain on that path.

Some interpretations of quantum mechanics are deterministic.  Many worlds and Hidden variables, for example. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Many-worlds_interpretationhttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Broglie%E2%80%93Bohm_theory

The current commonly accepted state of quantum mechanics doesn’t help determinism, but it doesn’t refute it either. There is still room for strict determinism in various non-local hidden variable theories such as De Broglie–Bohm theory.

All these answers note that determinism != free will, but I think what OP was trying to convey is basically that if physical super determinism is true, then free will cannot exist, but physical super determinism being untrue is not sufficient for the existence of free will.

They are unrelated. Hard determinism, chaos theory and quantum randomness, all have something to do with the universe being random or 100% predictable. The only determinism linked to the free will debate is psychological determinism. Basically, psychological determinism states that our behaviour is determined by our strongest desire and as we do not decide or control which desire is stronger, we can't “make” decisions. We “realize”, we don't “decide”, and we then act appropriately. There is no room for choice anywhere in the process. Therefore our will is not free, but rather, a slave to our desires.

Is it possible to disprove determinism using the study of quantum mechanics? No. The most common interpretatiin of quantum mechanics is nondeterministic. However, bells theorem also admits other possibilities. Nonlocal determinism, in which details about particles everywhere in the universe instantly affect the particle.Retrocausality. The future affects the pastSuper determinism. The exact future of the universe has been determined since the big bang.So determinism has not been disproven, though it is not definitely true either. Why you are asking, and whether this is relevant are different matters though.

It depends on the interpretation. All interpretations agree on the results of measurements, yet they disagree on the nature of reality. Bohmian mechanics and the many worlds interpretation are deterministic.

Some quantum interactions are genuinely indeterminate.   Such as shooting electrons through a Sterm-Gerlach magnet.   One can never predict with certainty the the spin of the electron will be  after it passes through.

It was recognized long before quantum physics that determinism is not possible in complex systems. Using Newton’s Laws, you cannot predict the orbits of three objects revolving around each other. You need chaos theory for that. It provides a range of motions.

In a nutshell: you can hang on to determinism and realism by adopting a Bohmian interpretation of QM. But no matter how you twist and turn you cannot escape the nonlocal influences that are inherent in QM. Some of what happens “here” is determined by events that are too far away to affect here classically.
No. (For example: Bohmian mechanics)
